context:
Speaker: David , what have you been up to lately ?
Listener: I went on a trip with my family last week .
Speaker: Really ? Where did you go ?
Listener: We went to Europe .
Speaker: What cities did you go to ?
Listener: London , Paris and a few other cities .
Speaker: Did you go to Berlin ?
Listener: No , We didn't go there . I'd like to go there next time .
Speaker: I think this summer is a good time to visit Berlin . It's a beautiful place and the people there are very nice .
Listener: That's what I've heard .
Speaker: I went there last year . If you want , I can give you some information I have about the city .
question: What is an emotion or human drive that motivates Speaker based on what they just said?
a1: to help others have a great travel experience by providing information.
a2: the speaker wants to share his experience in the city.

context:
Speaker: Have any plans for the weekend , Tom ?
Listener: Yeah , I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains .
Speaker: Oh , do you go hiking often ?
Listener: I go as much as I can . I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature .
Speaker: It would be nice to get out of the city . Do you want some company ?
Listener: Sure . But , it will be a long hike , 30 miles in three days . Have you been hiking before ?
Speaker: Yeah , I go a lot too . I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike .
Listener: Wow ! You must have been pretty far away from the city .
Speaker: Yeah , my friend and I hiked in a very wild part of the national forest .
Listener: Well , bring him along too . We ’ ll have a great time this weekend .
Speaker: Thanks , I ’ ll ask him .
question: What is an emotion or human drive that motivates Speaker based on what they just said?
a1: the speaker is happy here.
a2: by the opportunity to escape the city and connect with nature.

context:

a2: the speaker is angry and disappointed with the listener.

context:
Speaker: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
Listener: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
Speaker: Oh? What are you watching?
Listener: I'm watching a cowboy film.
Speaker: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
Listener: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
Speaker: What is he reading?
Listener: He's reading a magazine.
Speaker: What about Kate?
Listener: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
Speaker: Oh? Who's she calling?
Listener: She's calling her boyfriend.
Speaker: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
question: What is an emotion or human drive that motivates Speaker based on what they just said?
a1: the speaker wants to seek help from mr.jack.
a2: by a fear of not doing well in their class if they don't complete their homework.

context:
Listener: Hello, everyone. Welcome to our program. Today, we are fortunate to have a special guest with us. Some of you may have heard of him before. He's an artist. His works have received many prizes and have been shown in over one hundred exhibitions across the country - Los Angeles, New York, Philadelphia, to name just a few. His name is Chris Cucksy. So Chris, tell us a bit about yourself.
Speaker: Well, I was born in Springfield, Missouri, and grew up in Kansas. I didn't come from a family with wealth or position, but I did manage to get a master's degree in fine arts.
Listener: When did you first start to make art? And what was the turning point in your life that made you an artist?
Speaker: I always liked drawing as early as I can remember, so right from then, I knew what I was going to be: an artist.
Listener: What is it that always inspires you to create?
Speaker: Nature is the biggest inspiration. I'm always inspired by things of beauty and harmony.
question: What is an emotion or human drive that motivates Speaker based on what they just said?
a1: chris likes to be around nature to refresh his mind.
a2: by a drive to capture the essence and spirit of the natural world through their art.
